title: Why does organic solute dissolve in organic solvents? - Quora

response.answer_text: Organic solutes tend to have many C-H bonds for instance alkanes, benzene, which are non polar due to low electronegativity differences. Hence predominant intermolecular forces (solute-solute) are van der waals interactions. Similarly for organic solvents like hexane, many C-H bonds are present, and VDW forces are also predominant. For solubility, dissolution occurs when solute-solvent interactions are equal to or greater than solute-solute & solvent-solvent interactions. Or an easier way to put it would be that like dissolves like. Since all interactions here are VDW forces, dissolution occurs

Yeah like dissolves like ,as polar solvent dissolves polar ,and nonpolar dissolves nonpolar.basically what happens when you add polar organic compound in other polar compound , they try to come in same phase vai diffn kind of intractions as vanderwaal’s attraction.
